solution.p: Multiply each term of the first binomial be each term of the second binomial. This gives four multiplications, often denoted by "FOIL," which stands for First terms, Outside terms, Inside terms, and Last terms. \begin{alignat}{11} \amp \qquad(2x+3)(x-6) = \amp \amp \underline{x \cdot x} {}+{} \amp \amp\underline{2x \cdot (-6)} {}+{} \amp \amp\underline{(-3) \cdot x} {}+{} \amp \amp\underline{(-3) \cdot (-6)}\\ \amp \amp \amp \quad \alert{\text{F}}\amp \amp \qquad \alert{\text{O}}\amp \amp \qquad \alert{\text{I}}\amp \amp \qquad \alert{\text{L}}\\ \amp = 2x^2-12x-3x+18 \amp\amp\amp \amp ~\quad\blert{\text{Combine}}\amp \amp\blert{\text{like terms.}}\\ \amp = 2x^2-15x+18 \end{alignat}
First, multiply the binomial factors together. (3x-4)(3x-5) = 9x^2-27x+20 Then multiply the result by the monomial factor, -2. \alert{-2}(9x^2-27x+20) = -18x^2+54x-40

assemblage.title: Sign Patterns for Quadratic Trinomials
assemblage.p:
Assume that b,~c,~p and q are positive integers. Then
x^2+bx+c = (x+p)(x+q)
If all the coefficients of the trinomial are positive, then both p and q are positive.
x^2-bx+c = (x-p)(x-q)
If the middle term of the trinomial is negative and the other two terms are positive, then p and q are both negative.
x^2 \pm bx-c = (x+p)(x-q)
If the constant term of the trinomial is negative, then p and q have opposite signs.

statement.p: Factor ~t^2+7t+12~ as a product of two binomials, t^2+7t+12 = (t+p)(t+q)

solution.p: The constant term is 12, so we look for two numbers p and q whose product is 12. There are three possibilities: \text{ 1 and 12, 2 and 6, or 3 and 4} Because the middle term is 7t, we must have p+q=7. We check each possibility and find that p=3 and q=4. Thus, t^2+7t+12 = (t+3)(t+4)

For this example we must find two numbers p and q for which pq=20 and p+q=-12. These two conditions tell us that p and q must both be negative. We start by listing all the ways to factor 20 with negative factors: -1~~\text{and}~~-20,~~~~-2~~\text{and}~~-10,~~~~-4~~\text{and}~~-5 We check p+q for each possibility to see which one gives the correct middle term. Because -2+(-10) = -12, the factorization is x^2-12x+20 = (x-2)(x-10)

This time the product pq must be negative, so p and q must have opposite signs, one positive and one negative. There are only two ways to factor 15, either 1 times 15 or 3 times 5. We just "guess" that the second factor is negative, and check p+q for each possibility: 1-15=-14~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~3-5=-2 The middle term we want is 2x, not -2x, so we change the signs of p and q: we use -3and +5. The correct factorization is x^2+2x-15 = (x-3)(x+5)
Use extraction of roots. Isolate the squared expression. \begin{aligned}[t] x^2 \amp = 16 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Take square roots.}}\\ x \amp = \pm 4 \end{aligned} The solutions are x=4 and x=-4.

Solve by factoring. Get zero on one side of the equation. \begin{aligned}[t] 3x^2-12x \amp = 0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Factor the left side.}}\\ 3x(x-4) \amp = 0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Set each factor equal to zero.}}\\ 3x=0,~~~~x-4 \amp = 0 \end{aligned} The solutions are x=0 and x=4.

Solve by factoring. Factor the left side. \begin{aligned}[t] (x-4)(3x+2) \amp = 0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Set each factor equal to zero.}}\\ x-4=0,~~~~3x+2 \amp = 0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation.}}\\ x=4,~~~~x\amp = \dfrac{-2}{3} \end{aligned} The solutions are x=0 and x=\dfrac{-2}{3}.
